project_metadata.paper_title: Measure Twice, Cut Once: Cooperative Deployment of a Generalized, Archaeology-Specific Field Data Collection System
project_metadata.journal: In: Mobilizing the Past for a Digital Future: The Potential of Digital Archaeology, edited by Erin Walcek Averett, Jody Michael Gordon, and Derek B. Counts, pp. 337-371. Grand Forks, ND: The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota
project_metadata.research_context: Co-development case study examining cooperative deployment of the FAIMS (Federated Archaeological Information Management Systems) mobile platform across three archaeological projects: Boncuklu Höyük (Turkey), MEMSAP (Malawi), and PAZC (Peru). Analyses the trade-offs between features and performance, the participatory design process, and the benefits of generalised archaeology-specific field data collection systems compared to commercial or bespoke alternatives.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS project launched in 2012 to develop national archaeological information management infrastructure
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project is a university-based, e-research initiative that was launched in 2012 to develop national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology and related disciplines

evidence.evidence_text: Initial NeCTAR funding of AUD $949,500 for FAIMS development
evidence.verbatim_quote: It was initially based at the University of New South Wales, Sydney, and funded by a grant from the Australian National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program (RT043; AUD $949,500)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS mobile platform entered public beta in November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: the FAIMS project developed a generalised, mobile, offline, multi-user collection platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data (the "FAIMS mobile platform," discussed below), which entered public beta release in November 2013

evidence.evidence_text: ARC LIEF award of AUD $945,000 total funding received in 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2014, the FAIMS project received an Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities (LIEF) award (LE140100151; AUD $945,000 total ARC funding and university co-investment)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS 2.0 released in November 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: Experience from these deployments informed ongoing development of FAIMS software, resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0, the current production version, in November 2014

evidence.evidence_text: Service fees account for approximately 5% of FAIMS budget with infrastructure grants comprising 95%
evidence.verbatim_quote: To date, fees have accounted for about 5% of the FAIMS budget, with infrastructure grants constituting the other 95%—although these figures exclude in-kind contributions of time by academic staff and other participants, which, for example, total approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone

evidence.evidence_text: In-kind contributions total approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone
evidence.verbatim_quote: although these figures exclude in-kind contributions of time by academic staff and other participants, which, for example, total approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone

evidence.evidence_text: Two doctoral student projects successfully customised and deployed their own FAIMS systems
evidence.verbatim_quote: Two small projects, both undertaken by doctoral students, have successfully customised and deployed their own systems

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS team created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 in the field since November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since the public release of our software in November 2013

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Pre-configured local server costs AUD $1,700-$3,500 excluding tablets
evidence.verbatim_quote: Purchasing a pre-configured local server with all necessary hardware costs AUD $1,700–$3,500 from one of these vendors (excluding tablets)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Server can be leased for approximately AUD $150-$200 per month
evidence.verbatim_quote: Alternatively, an online or local server can be leased for approximately AUD $150–$200 per month

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Customisation costs range from AUD $1,500-$15,000 per season depending on complexity
evidence.verbatim_quote: When a project hires the FAIMS team to adapt an existing module or develop a new one, this service generally costs approximately AUD $1,500–$15,000 per season for the mobile platform, depending on the complexity and novelty of the recording system required

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu and MEMSAP customisation valued at approximately $15,000 each for first year
evidence.verbatim_quote: Customisation and support work for the Boncuklu and MEMSAP projects presented here, for example, was valued about $15,000 each for their first year of deployment (but only $3,250 for a subsequent deployment for Boncuklu)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Subsequent Boncuklu deployment cost only $3,250
evidence.verbatim_quote: but only $3,250 for a subsequent deployment for Boncuklu

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC first year cost only $900 due to module reuse
evidence.verbatim_quote: Because the PAZC project was willing to reuse an existing module, their first year cost only $900 (a subsequent deployment cost $2,400, after they identified some additional modifications)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu excavation involves fine layering with single context recording within <5cm of deposit
evidence.verbatim_quote: One peculiarity of the site is its extremely fine layering and the complex intercutting of archaeological features, caused by rebuilding of houses on the same site time and time again. . . . [a single context in] Boncuklu may be resolved within <5 cm of deposit

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

evidence.evidence_text: MEMSAP recording system based on single-context form-based system modified from Marean et al. (2010)
evidence.verbatim_quote: MEMSAP based its excavation recording system on a single-context form-based system modified from Marean et al. (2010)

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC used single-context recording on paper forms in 2012
evidence.verbatim_quote: In our 2012 field season at Carrizales, PAZC team members recorded data using a single-context recording system on paper forms

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

evidence.evidence_text: Three iterations of excavation module and two iterations of survey module needed before functional deployment
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ultimately only three iterations of the excavation module and two iterations of the survey module were needed before a functional system could be deployed in the field

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC module produced in approximately three and a half weeks from first contact to deployment
evidence.verbatim_quote: The total time that elapsed between first contact with FAIMS leadership and deployment of the finished PAZC module was approximately three and a half weeks

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu module translation and customisation required less than one week after full specification
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS team translated the Boncuklu module into Spanish and customised it where required by editing the Boncuklu definition documents, a process that required less than one week after the requirements were fully specified

evidence.evidence_text: Records that initially took 20 minutes eventually took over an hour due to performance degradation
evidence.verbatim_quote: More serious was the slowdown of the system halfway through its period of use. A record which initially took 20 minutes to input took over an hour due to slow syncing and updating

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn received data before paper forms arrived in Australia
evidence.verbatim_quote: [I have received the CSV file and] the data are present and useable. I am now waiting for [the other project director] to send me the forms

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: MEMSAP tablets saved at least eight person-days of work on data integration
evidence.verbatim_quote: When the scope of data entry, cleaning, analysis, and archiving is considered, the tablets saved at least eight person-days of work, although this may have been an extreme case because one of the main post-season challenges [during previous seasons] was the integration of both paper and tablet data into a single database

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn quantified post-processing at 2-3 hours compared to several hundred hours for >300 context records
evidence.verbatim_quote: The greatest gains in the FAIMS system were found after the excavation season was finished with post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records generated in a typical season

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: Labour savings equivalent to AU$5,000-10,000 per annum in paid RA time
evidence.verbatim_quote: This saving in paid RA time equates to c. AU$5,000–10,000 per annum

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: 95% labour saving: 1-1.5 days handling time with FAIMS versus 25-30 days without
evidence.verbatim_quote: The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum, in other words a 95% labour saving

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: Six person-hours spent investigating transcription errors in MEMSAP paper records
evidence.verbatim_quote: nor did they suffer from the inevitable transcription error that in this case cost at least six person-hours to investigate and rectify

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps using online server
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using this system, our upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps—too slow for syncing, even when tablets were left to do so overnight

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS-in-a-box hardware worked well despite dusty conditions and unreliable electricity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Also, it is worth noting that the equipment—FAIMS-in-a-box—worked very well and with the exception of 1 tablet screen—cracked when an item fell on it from the edge of the trench—came through the season in great condition. This was in spite of very dusty conditions and a somewhat unreliable electricity supply

evidence.evidence_text: WiFi provided 75-80% signal strength at 80m distance
evidence.verbatim_quote: the [wifi] provided excellent coverage (75–80% signal strength at 80m, the furthest excavation trench

evidence.evidence_text: All FAIMS project software is free and open source under GPLv.3 licence
evidence.verbatim_quote: All FAIMS project software is free and open source (GPLv.3 licence)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Server hung only once when UPS plug was knocked out during power outage
evidence.verbatim_quote: The server hung only once, when the UPS plug was knocked out during a power outage, but was simply re-booted using an external keyboard

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson's context identifier encoded five separate variables
evidence.verbatim_quote: Thompson's "2228|SS|11|I|F5" identifier, for example, encapsulates the distinct attributes of LotID, Site Code, Context ID, AreaCode, and Grid Location Reference

evidence.evidence_text: Project moved to Macquarie University Sydney in January 2015
evidence.verbatim_quote: The project moved to Macquarie University, Sydney, in January 2015

claims.claim_text: Generalised, open-source tools designed for field research bring the advantages of bespoke software within reach of typical projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Generalised, open-source tools designed for field research bring the advantages of bespoke software within reach of "typical" projects

claims.claim_text: FAIMS is a university-based e-research initiative developing national archaeological information management infrastructure
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project is a university-based, e-research initiative that was launched in 2012 to develop national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology and related disciplines

claims.claim_text: FAIMS secured substantial infrastructure funding from NeCTAR and ARC LIEF programs
claims.verbatim_quote: funded by a grant from the Australian National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program (RT043; AUD $949,500)

claims.claim_text: FAIMS developed a generalised mobile platform for diverse archaeological data types
claims.verbatim_quote: the FAIMS project developed a generalised, mobile, offline, multi-user collection platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data

claims.claim_text: Deployments informed ongoing FAIMS development through iterative feedback
claims.verbatim_quote: Experience from these deployments informed ongoing development of FAIMS software, resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0, the current production version, in November 2014

claims.claim_text: FAIMS sustainability depends primarily on infrastructure grants with service fees comprising small portion
claims.verbatim_quote: We envision that within five years, service fees will constitute perhaps 25% of our budget, but the project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions

claims.claim_text: Some users can successfully customise and deploy FAIMS independently
claims.verbatim_quote: Two small projects, both undertaken by doctoral students, have successfully customised and deployed their own systems

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: FAIMS team has extensive experience supporting field deployments across multiple projects
claims.verbatim_quote: to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since the public release of our software in November 2013

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Number of supported projects likely to double by end of 2017
claims.verbatim_quote: That number is likely to double by the end of 2017

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: FAIMS offers accessible pricing for purpose-built field recording software
claims.verbatim_quote: It is our hope that by building free and open-source software to high standards using research infrastructure funding, by providing extensive documentation and as much support as possible for do-it-yourselfers, by building a library of modules for various activities, and by offering customisation, deployment, and support services at a reasonable cost, we can deliver purpose-built field-recording software to projects and organisations who otherwise could not afford it

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Complex module development requires significant initial investment but reduces subsequent deployment costs
claims.verbatim_quote: Deployments of a module for subsequent seasons are usually less expensive because users only pay for changes and support

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Module reuse offers substantial cost savings over new development
claims.verbatim_quote: Because the PAZC project was willing to reuse an existing module, their first year cost only $900 (a subsequent deployment cost $2,400, after they identified some additional modifications), illustrating the savings that redeployment can offer

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Customisation costs can be recouped from later savings in data digitisation and reconciliation
claims.verbatim_quote: As will be seen below, customisation and support costs of this magnitude can be largely recouped from later savings in data digitisation and reconciliation, aside from any other benefits of digital recording

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Boncuklu requires fine-grained single-context recording due to complex stratigraphy
claims.verbatim_quote: As a result, excavation has necessarily been fine-grained, utilising a single context recording method better to understand the subtle interrelationships of the site's building sequences and extra-mural areas

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

claims.claim_text: All three case study projects employed variants of single-context recording methods
claims.verbatim_quote: MEMSAP based its excavation recording system on a single-context form-based system

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

claims.claim_text: MEMSAP achieved rapid module deployment because data categories had been worked out in previous seasons
claims.verbatim_quote: Ultimately only three iterations of the excavation module and two iterations of the survey module were needed before a functional system could be deployed in the field. However, this was likely because all of the data categories and relationships had been worked out—in paper version—over the course of previous field seasons

claims.claim_text: Generalised systems can spawn new deployments more rapidly than bespoke or general-purpose systems
claims.verbatim_quote: As this example illustrates, a system with a generalised core can spawn new deployments rapidly in a way that neither bespoke nor general-purpose systems can

claims.claim_text: Module reuse and adaptation is faster than creating new modules from scratch
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS team translated the Boncuklu module into Spanish and customised it where required by editing the Boncuklu definition documents, a process that required less than one week after the requirements were fully specified

claims.claim_text: Complex auto-generated identifiers caused exponential performance degradation
claims.verbatim_quote: Performance degradation was barely perceptible during testing, which involved only a few records, but it worsened exponentially as the database grew (more precisely, as a square function of the number of records)

claims.claim_text: Digital data was available for analysis immediately after fieldwork while paper forms were still in transit
claims.verbatim_quote: He received his comma separated value (CSV; a standard spreadsheet-type format) data files and created an Access database from them, all in the time before the paper forms (used as a backup to FAIMS as part of the transition to digital recording) arrived at Australia

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Digital recording produced substantial time savings compared to paper-based approaches
claims.verbatim_quote: When the scope of data entry, cleaning, analysis, and archiving is considered, the tablets saved at least eight person-days of work

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Time investment before fieldwork pays off with time saved digitising and cleansing data
claims.verbatim_quote: While many projects prefer to collect data first and spend effort cleaning it later, our partners chose to invest effort before fieldwork, in order to have cleaner, richer data for immediate analysis

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Digital recording eliminates transcription errors inherent in paper-based workflows
claims.verbatim_quote: There were fewer errors made in data recording with the tablets, and the pre-defined categories made the data far easier to sort, search, and analyse

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Online server approach failed due to inadequate bandwidth in remote field locations
claims.verbatim_quote: Using this system, our upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps—too slow for syncing, even when tablets were left to do so overnight

claims.claim_text: Local dedicated hardware servers are more reliable than online servers for remote fieldwork
claims.verbatim_quote: Local, dedicated hardware servers are more expensive than online servers, and they require that users test and maintain them, but they are faster and more robust than online servers

claims.claim_text: FAIMS software is freely available under open source licence
claims.verbatim_quote: All FAIMS project software is free and open source (GPLv.3 licence)

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Exceptional support is necessary when deploying new technology in the field
claims.verbatim_quote: Exceptional support is necessary when deploying new technology in the field, especially software that is purpose-built for the research community

claims.claim_text: Converting from paper to digital requires making implicit knowledge explicit
claims.verbatim_quote: Converting from paper to digital workflows is an involved and time-consuming process. It requires making the implicit knowledge embedded in paper forms explicit

claims.claim_text: Established projects with stable procedures have advantage during software customisation
claims.verbatim_quote: Established projects with stable procedures have an advantage during software customisation, since they can articulate requirements and priorities quickly and coherently

claims.claim_text: Trade-offs between features and performance must be carefully managed during module development
claims.verbatim_quote: The shared responsibilities of developers and researchers are perhaps clearest in the context of the trade-offs between features and performance that must be made during the production of a field recording system

claims.claim_text: Digital forms must be more precise and complete than paper forms to maintain data quality advantages
claims.verbatim_quote: Paper forms can approximate the desired data collection strategy, with exceptions, omissions, and edge cases written in the margins or on the back of the form. Despite some FAIMS features like the "annotations" field embedded in all attributes where users can make contextual notes, which reproduce the freedom of the paper page, digital forms must be more precise and complete, or their primary advantage—the production of clean, consistent data—is lost

claims.claim_text: Testing must occur on each specific device to avoid compatibility problems
claims.verbatim_quote: Software that worked during internal testing by the FAIMS team (or even by archaeologists prior to fieldwork) did not always work on different tablets, even if they were made by the same manufacturer. These compatibility problems are the price paid for the wide range of devices offered within the Android ecosystem. It therefore proved necessary to test the FAIMS mobile platform on each device

claims.claim_text: Archaeologists tend to prioritise feature development at expense of testing
claims.verbatim_quote: In the FAIMS experience, archaeologists tended to prioritise the development of new features at the expense of testing. This is hardly surprising, as feature development is exciting and novel, as opposed to the rote, but essential, work of testing

claims.claim_text: Digital recording improved both richness and integrity of field data at PAZC
claims.verbatim_quote: our final review of data collected by the PAZC in 2014 suggests that using FAIMS improved both the richness and integrity of our data. Context descriptions are generally more detailed, and the range of fields in the FAIMS default module meant that project members recorded types of data (such as parameters of soil matrices and inclusions) that we had formerly treated in an inconsistent fashion

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Digital data enabled timely discovery of recording errors that would otherwise go undetected
claims.verbatim_quote: Finally, Fairbairn discovered an unexpected benefit of having his digital data available immediately: the timely discovery of errors. "I also can see all the inconsistent entries that were made by people who should know better." His data was digital and ready for review promptly at the end of the season, which revealed problems that would otherwise have gone undetected until the paper forms were digitised—perhaps months later—when the errors would have been far more difficult to correct

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Digital recording opens broader dialogue about recording process and increases awareness of challenges
claims.verbatim_quote: [I]mportantly, the technology has opened up a broader dialogue about the recording process, increased awareness in the excavation group of the challenges and requirements of recording and opened a quite fixed system to change

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: More continuous digital recordkeeping may contribute toward making workflows more transparent and reproducible
claims.verbatim_quote: More continuous recordkeeping, including of "messy" work-in-progress, not only helps researchers at a later time better understand what they have excavated, but may contribute toward both making workflows more transparent and "openly exposing the process of research" (Kansa, Ch. 4.2), thus improving the reproducibility and professionalism of field research

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: Software co-development in a generalised framework is difficult but productive
claims.verbatim_quote: Software co-development in a generalised framework like FAIMS, involving a genuine partnership between archaeologists and technologists, is a difficult but productive process that can yield systems that are effective and fit-to-purpose

claims.claim_text: FAIMS strikes good balance between re-deployability and domain-specific capability
claims.verbatim_quote: The authors of this paper believe that FAIMS strikes a good balance between the re-deployability of general-purpose database software and the domain- and project-specific capability of bespoke applications

claims.claim_text: FAIMS can operate offline and synchronise whenever WiFi is available
claims.verbatim_quote: To accommodate these conditions, devices running FAIMS have no need for a continuous connection to maintain data integrity; they happily operate offline and synchronise whenever a Wi-Fi network is available (according to configurable rules)

claims.claim_text: FileMaker requires workarounds when asked to collect data simultaneously on multiple offline devices
claims.verbatim_quote: The FileMaker application and DBMS, conversely, have been designed for more "normal" deployment situations, and they operate grudgingly in a network-degraded field environment, requiring work-arounds when asked to collect data simultaneously on multiple offline devices

claims.claim_text: FAIMS was developed around the expressed requirements of archaeologists to manage field conditions
claims.verbatim_quote: It does not make sense for FileMaker to optimise for these unusual conditions, as they require significant trade-offs in complexity and performance, and return benefits only in specific and limited situations. FileMaker was designed for everyone; FAIMS was developed around the expressed requirements of archaeologists to manage the high-friction environment of fieldwork

claims.claim_text: A bespoke app may outperform FAIMS for single tasks but at considerable cost
claims.verbatim_quote: A bespoke Android or iOS app, if properly resourced and designed, may outperform FAIMS for any single data collection task, but at considerable cost

claims.claim_text: Development and maintenance costs of bespoke software exceed resources of most projects
claims.verbatim_quote: The requirements gathering, planning, development, and testing required to produce software reliable enough for field archaeology are expensive and demanding. Even after development is "complete," software has significant maintenance costs such as bug-fixing and keeping up with the biennial mobile OS update cycle

claims.claim_text: Shared core library allows fixed costs of development to be shared across users
claims.verbatim_quote: Because the core FAIMS software is common to all deployments, however, the fixed costs of development and maintenance can be shared across many users, projects, and institutions

claims.claim_text: Open-source co-development allows archaeologists to participate in software development rather than just consume
claims.verbatim_quote: Perhaps more importantly, generalised tools also allow archaeologists to participate in software development, not merely consume software. Such co-development involves a partnership between field archaeologists and a software development team

claims.claim_text: Participating in open-source development involves responsibilities, trade-offs, and significant benefits
claims.verbatim_quote: Participating in open-source development is different from buying software from a vendor. There are responsibilities, trade-offs, and significant benefits

claims.claim_text: FAIMS treats complex archaeological work with appropriate seriousness as miniature software development projects
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS treats complex archaeological work with the seriousness it deserves. The FAIMS approach, partly dictated by the nature of the software and partly by our experience, has us treat each deployment as an authentic, miniature software development project that requires proper "scoping" (requirements gathering, software design, and development planning), coding, and "quality assurance" (testing at each step of development to ensure that software works and is fit-to-purpose)

claims.claim_text: The full impact of digital recording requires post-fieldwork analysis and data publication
claims.verbatim_quote: VanValkenburgh noted that the full impact of digital recording would not be clear until after post-fieldwork analysis and integration were complete. Looking even further ahead, digitally born data makes the timely publication of datasets more likely: "the ready availability . . . of our digital data is going to greatly facilitate making it publicly accessible in approximately two years."

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: Comparative and synthetic research will realise the greatest interpretive impact of digital methods
claims.verbatim_quote: It is perhaps at the comparative or synthetic level, beyond individual projects, that we should seek the greatest interpretive impact. Only after digital datasets are published and researchers start reusing and combining them will the full potential and impact of digital methods be realised

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The comparison of FAIMS to commercial and bespoke alternatives is valid because all three approaches address the same fundamental archaeological data collection needs
trigger_text: Archaeologists face an immediate, fundamental decision once they decide to digitise field data collection: put together a solution from several pieces of general-purpose, usually proprietary, software aimed at the commercial market
FAIMS lies near the middle of this spectrum
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper compares FAIMS against commercial and bespoke solutions throughout but assumes without argument that these approaches are comparable because they address equivalent needs. The implicit assumption bridges the evidence about each approach to comparative claims.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Time savings from digital recording outweigh the upfront investment in module development and testing
trigger_text: The greatest gains in the FAIMS system were found after the excavation season was finished with post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours
Customisation and support costs of this magnitude can be largely recouped from later savings in data digitisation and reconciliation

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

trigger_locations.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents time savings evidence and asserts costs are recouped, but the full cost-benefit accounting (including all upfront time, learning curves, and ongoing maintenance) is implicit rather than systematically demonstrated.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The three case study projects are representative of typical archaeological field projects that might adopt FAIMS
trigger_text: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences deploying FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork
Generalised, open-source tools designed for field research bring the advantages of bespoke software within reach of "typical" projects

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper draws conclusions about FAIMS suitability for 'typical' projects based on three case studies, but these are projects with university affiliations, ARC funding connections, and willingness to be early adopters - potentially not representative of all archaeological projects.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Project directors' self-reported experiences and quantified benefits accurately reflect the actual costs and benefits of FAIMS deployment
trigger_text: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires, and also exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork. These sources provide the quotations below
The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Quantitative claims about labour savings are based on project director self-reports rather than independent measurement. The accuracy of these estimates is assumed but not verified.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The lessons from 2014 deployments remain applicable to future FAIMS users despite ongoing software evolution
trigger_text: Experience from these deployments informed ongoing development of FAIMS software, resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0
The case studies presented here offer lessons applicable to any field software development project
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents lessons learned from 2014 deployments as generally applicable, but the software has evolved since then. The assumption that lessons remain valid despite software changes is implicit.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The challenges encountered in these deployments are primarily attributable to co-development process characteristics rather than FAIMS-specific limitations
trigger_text: The case studies presented here offer lessons applicable to any field software development project, including customisation of commercial software or development of bespoke applications
As such, the authors believe that our experience also offers lessons to those who choose to customise commercial DBMS software
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper frames deployment challenges as generic to software co-development rather than specific to FAIMS architecture. This allows generalisation of lessons but assumes issues are not FAIMS-specific without comparative evidence.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The continuing viability of FAIMS as infrastructure depends on maintaining current funding levels and institutional support
trigger_text: the project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions
This funding allows the FAIMS project to employ a professional software engineering team
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The sustainability claims depend on continued grant funding, but the paper presents FAIMS as stable infrastructure without explicitly acknowledging the contingency of this funding-dependent model.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Data quality improvements from digital recording are primarily due to the recording system rather than user training or experience effects
trigger_text: There were fewer errors made in data recording with the tablets, and the pre-defined categories made the data far easier to sort, search, and analyse

Context descriptions are generally more detailed, and the range of fields in the FAIMS default module meant that project members recorded types of data... that we had formerly treated in an inconsistent fashion

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data
The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Improvements are attributed to the digital system, but the deployments also involved training, scoping conversations, and heightened awareness that could independently improve recording quality. Causal attribution to the system is implicit.

research_designs.design_text: Case study methodology to examine co-development experiences through thematic analysis of three FAIMS deployments
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This paper presents experiences from the first production deployments of the FAIMS mobile platform, drawing on the observations of the FAIMS team and three project directors who deployed the platform during their 2014 field seasons

research_designs.design_text: Comparative framing positioning FAIMS between commercial off-the-shelf and bespoke software alternatives
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Archaeologists face an immediate, fundamental decision once they decide to digitise field data collection: put together a solution from several pieces of general-purpose, usually proprietary, software aimed at the commercial market . . . or develop and customise a solution from scratch

research_designs.design_text: Selection of three diverse case studies spanning different geographic and disciplinary contexts (Turkey/Neolithic, Malawi/Palaeolithic, Peru/Colonial)
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences deploying FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

research_designs.design_text: Thematic organisation of findings around three cross-cutting themes derived from deployment experiences
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We highlight three themes from the case-studies: (1) upfront costs and backend payouts, (2) trade-offs and shared lessons, and (3) archaeological interpretation

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

research_designs.design_text: Reflective practitioner perspective with authors serving dual roles as FAIMS developers and case study participants
trigger_text: The FAIMS project is a university-based, e-research initiative
This paper presents experiences from the first production deployments of the FAIMS mobile platform
research_designs.inference_reasoning: Authors are both FAIMS team members and paper authors, but this dual role and its implications for objectivity are not explicitly acknowledged or discussed.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Positionality of authors as FAIMS developers conducting evaluation of own software not explicitly discussed
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether findings may be influenced by developer perspective

methods.method_text: Post-deployment questionnaire and correspondence analysis with project directors
methods.verbatim_quote: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires, and also exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork. These sources provide the quotations below

methods.verbatim_quote: We highlight three themes from the case-studies: (1) upfront costs and backend payouts, (2) trade-offs and shared lessons, and (3) archaeological interpretation

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

methods.method_text: Quantitative cost-benefit analysis comparing digital versus paper-based workflows
methods.verbatim_quote: The greatest gains in the FAIMS system were found after the excavation season was finished with post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records generated in a typical season

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

protocols.protocol_text: Documentation of FAIMS deployment records including module iterations, customisation timelines, and cost valuations
trigger_text: to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field
Customisation and support work for the Boncuklu and MEMSAP projects presented here, for example, was valued about $15,000 each

trigger_locations.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform
Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper reports specific deployment counts and cost valuations, implying systematic record-keeping, but documentation procedures are not described.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Procedures for tracking deployments and calculating costs not specified
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot verify cost calculation methodology or completeness of deployment records

protocols.protocol_text: Thematic coding of case study experiences into three predetermined themes
trigger_text: We highlight three themes from the case-studies
These three themes are intended to provide guidance for those who choose the same generalised, open-source approach

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation
Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper organises findings into three themes but does not describe how themes were derived or how data was coded to themes.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Theme derivation process and coding procedures not documented
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether themes emerged from data or were predetermined, or whether all relevant themes were captured

protocols.protocol_text: Time and cost comparison calculations based on project director estimates
trigger_text: The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum
This saving in paid RA time equates to c. AU$5,000–10,000 per annum

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data
The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

protocols.inference_reasoning: Paper reports specific time and cost savings but does not describe how these were calculated or what assumptions underlie the comparisons.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Calculation methodology for time/cost comparisons not specified; baseline comparison conditions unclear
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot verify accuracy of savings calculations or assess whether comparisons are valid

orcid_coverage.notes: No ORCIDs found in extracted text. This is a 2016 book chapter; ORCID adoption was minimal in HASS at this time.

data_availability.verbatim_statement: No formal data availability statement. Module definition documents referenced as available via GitHub and supplementary materials.

repositories.name: GitHub FAIMS
repositories.description: Module definition documents and source code

data_availability.notes: Case study data (questionnaires, communications) available in supplementary materials. No formal data repository or DOI.

code_availability.verbatim_statement: All FAIMS project software is free and open source (GPLv.3 licence)

repositories.name: GitHub FAIMS
repositories.description: FAIMS mobile platform and server software, module definition documents

code_availability.documentation_level: Extensive - formal documentation developed with 2015 NeCTAR grant

author_contributions.notes: No formal author contributions statement. From paper context: Sobotkova, Ross, Ballsun-Stanton are FAIMS team members; Fairbairn, Thompson, VanValkenburgh are case study project directors who provided deployment experiences.

conflicts_of_interest.notes: No COI statement. Implicit conflict: several authors are FAIMS team members evaluating their own software.

ethics_approval.notes: Not applicable - methodological paper about software deployment, not human subjects research. Case studies involved archaeological fieldwork, not human participants.

permits_and_authorizations.notes: Archaeological fieldwork permits for the three case study sites (Boncuklu, MEMSAP, PAZC) not discussed in this paper. Focus is on software deployment, not fieldwork permissions.

preregistration.notes: Not applicable - methodological case study paper, not hypothesis-testing research.

materials.description: FAIMS module definition documents for three case study deployments (Boncuklu excavation module, MEMSAP excavation and survey modules, PAZC excavation module)
Project director questionnaires and communications (post-project questionnaires, email exchanges, chat messages)

supplementary_materials.notes: Supplementary materials referenced as available through the digital supplement to the volume. No external repository URLs provided.

references_completeness.notes: References section truncated in processed markdown. Unable to assess DOI coverage.

findable.rationale: F1: No DOI for paper. F2: Basic bibliographic metadata only. F3: N/A - no separate data deposit. F4: Book indexed in library catalogues and Google Scholar.

accessible.rationale: A1: No DOI resolver. A1.1: Open access book via Digital Press. A1.2: No authentication required. A2: No separate metadata record.

interoperable.rationale: I1: GitHub uses structured format. I2: No controlled vocabularies for metadata. I3: References to other FAIMS publications.

reusable.rationale: R1: Detailed methodology description. R1.1: GPLv.3 licence for software. R1.2: Development history documented. R1.3: No formal community standards compliance.

machine_actionability.rationale: Software available via GitHub (machine-readable). Paper and supplementary materials not machine-actionable - no structured metadata, no APIs, no DOIs.

discipline_context.expectations: Pre-2016 HASS baseline: ORCID adoption minimal (17-24%), DOIs for book chapters rare, data sharing practices emerging.
discipline_context.research_type: Methodological case study with software documentation
discipline_context.rationale: FAIR score of 50% is acceptable for 2016 book chapter. Software availability via GitHub is above average for the period. Lack of formal data DOIs reflects pre-FAIR era practices.

recommendations: Mint DOI for paper via open access repository (e.g., Zenodo)
Archive software release with Software Heritage or Zenodo DOI
Add author ORCIDs to institutional profiles
Create structured metadata record for supplementary materials

extraction_metadata.notes: Infrastructure extraction from processed markdown. No dedicated Data Availability or Author Contributions sections. Funding information extracted from body and acknowledgements. Open access book chapter with software repository links but no DOIs.

pass0_metadata.notes: Book chapter in edited volume. Full author names extracted from citation header. No DOI present - published as open access by The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota.

pass1_claims_evidence.notes: Methodological paper with extensive case study material. Strong emphasis on cost-benefit analysis and practical deployment lessons. Three case studies (Boncuklu, MEMSAP, PAZC) provide quantitative evidence for claims. Implicit arguments focus on representativeness, causal attribution, and sustainability assumptions.

pass3_5_rdmap.extraction_approach: Three-tier RDMAP hierarchy with explicit and implicit items
pass3_5_rdmap.notes: Case study methodology with thematic analysis. Most RDMAP items explicit. One implicit item (RD005 - positionality) captures undiscussed dual role of authors as FAIMS developers.

pass6_infrastructure.extraction_approach: Full infrastructure extraction with FAIR assessment
pass6_infrastructure.notes: 2016 book chapter with minimal PID infrastructure but good software availability via GitHub. No formal data/code availability statements. Supplementary materials include module definitions and project director communications.

pass7_validation.notes: Initial bidirectional validation found 4 conflicts requiring manual resolution. All resolved by adding missing reverse references. Final validation: 0 errors.
